snippet: Defenses at the American mission in Benghazi have become a major issue as the Obama administration struggles to explain what happened there and how Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens ended up alone.
abstract: Security at the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, has become major issue as the Obama administration struggles to explain what happened during recent deadly attack; officials say that an effective response by newly trained Libyan security guards to small bombing outside the mission in June may have led them to underestimate the security threat to personnel there.

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT, DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY
byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and David D. Kirkpatrick and Suliman Ali Zway from Benghazi, Libya. Steven Lee Myers and Michael S. Schmidt contributed reporting from Washington, and Kitty Bennett from Florida.

lead_paragraph: Defenses at the American mission in Benghazi have become a major issue as the Obama administration struggles to explain what happened there and how Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens ended up alone.

headline.seo: Mistaken Sense of Security Cited Before Envoy to Libya Died
headline.main: U.S. May Have Put Mistaken Faith in Libya Site’s Security
headline.print_headline: Mistaken Faith In Security Seen At Libya Mission
